Well, the thought is that you can have two kinds of evolutionary strategies, one of them which is the chicken strategy.
Is to be beautifully adapted for one particular evolutionary niche.

The other one which is the crow's strategy, is not to be terribly well adapted to anyone niche, but to be very very good at learning about many many different variable environments in which you find yourself, and that's a very good strategy, but it has one big drawback, which is that during the time that you're doing that learning, you're not actually going to be very good at acting.
You're not going to be very good at decision making.
You're not going to be very good at maximizing your utilities and the way that evolution seems to have solved that problem is by.
Letting your parents do the decision-making for you during the time when you're doing.

Now, developmentalists have found that in the first five years of life children are constructing and revising intuitive theories of the world around them, and they do this very spontaneously and we can chart the changes in the series they have of the world around them.

In the last 10 years, we've started to try to give a more precise account of how that kind of theory, formation and revision in the light of evidence is possible, and we've been using techniques from probabilistic models, particularly probabilistic causal models.
Things like causal graphs and directed causal Bayes Nets and then used ideas and techniques from Bayesian inference to describe how one might learn those kinds of causal graphs or causal models.

What they're doing is using that evidence to construct abstract causal models, and then using the causal models later on when they get to be adults to govern their behavior.
That's that's the picture.

And when you look at the way that Bayesian inference actually gets implemented in computer science, the solution to the search problem, or at least one solution to the search problem is various kinds of sampling.
So the idea is that rather than looking through all the hypothesis, you choose some subset of potential hypothesis.
Often things that are deviation small deviations from your current hypothesis.
And you test them those, and then you try moving to another part of the space and you test those and so forth.
And things like Markov chain Monte Carlo and particle filters use that kind of technique.
And there's some evidence that adults use that kind of Sam.

So one way that you can perform the searches, you can have a what?
People in machine learning call low temperature search where you're just searching very close to the solution.

They the place that you already are, so you might be working out the fine details of a solution that's close to where you already are, and that has the advantage that if, for example, you are trying to make a decision, you're more likely to satisfy, so you're more likely to get to a solution that's going to be pretty good.
It has the disadvantage that if the really best solution is far off in the space, you might never actually get there.
You might never actually find it.
On the other hand, the high temperature search can think about this box full of hypothesis that you're searching through, and a high temperature search.
You're going to move to much further parts of the space, and it's going to take much less data to move you from one hypothesis to another hypothesis.
So just a small amount of contradictory data will lead you further away from the place that you already are.
And again, this has the advantage that you're going to be able to learn more.
You're going to be able to learn more, especially.
About unlikely or implausible hypothesis ones that are far from where you currently are.

It has the disadvantage that you're going to be spending a lot of time off in parts of the space that actually aren't actually helpful, and you know, if the Mastodon is charging at you while you're trying to do this search, it's not going to be a very effective strategy.
So the way that the way that people in machine learning or at least one way that people in machine learning solve this problem.
One is through.

A process called simulated annealing and the idea is that you start out with this kind of early high temperature search where you're looking through lots and lots and lots of parts of the space in a pretty broad way.

You're sort of working out the broad outlines of the problem and then later on you settle into low temperature search looking for details, and that it's in the low temperature search space that you're likely to actually get the strategy that will be the most effective strategy.
